keyTakeAways: The Pakistani navy, operating under the Saudi-led Combined Maritime Forces (CMF), seized narcotics worth nearly $1 billion in the Arabian Sea over a 48-hour period.
The first seizure involved over 2 tonnes of crystal methamphetamine (ICE) valued at $822.4 million, intercepted on October 18, 2025.
The second seizure included 350 kg of ICE valued at $140 million and 50 kg of cocaine valued at $10 million, intercepted less than 48 hours later.
The vessels were identified as having no nationality, suggesting potential illicit trafficking routes.
The operation was conducted as part of CMF Task Force 150, a multinational naval initiative focused on maritime security and anti-smuggling efforts.
The success of the operation has been recognized by U.S. Central Command, highlighting international cooperation in combating drug trafficking.
The Pakistani navy emphasized its commitment to regional maritime security and global peace through such operations.

summaryOfNewsArticle: The Pakistani navy, operating under the Saudi-led Combined Maritime Forces (CMF), conducted two high-profile drug seizures in the Arabian Sea over a 48-hour period in late October 2025. The first interception on October 18 involved over 2 tonnes of crystal methamphetamine (ICE) valued at $822.4 million, while the second, less than 48 hours later, yielded 350 kg of ICE ($140 million) and 50 kg of cocaine ($10 million). The vessels, identified as having no nationality, were likely used for illicit trafficking. The operation, carried out by CMF Task Force 150, was praised by U.S. Central Command as one of the most successful narcotics seizures in CMF history, highlighting the effectiveness of multinational naval collaboration in countering drug trafficking through shared maritime surveillance and joint operations.
title: Pakistan navy seizes drugs worth nearly $1bn in the Arabian Sea
